Award.AwardTitle: A New Approach to Functionalized Organic and Metal Nanoparticles
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Steven C. Zimmerman of the University of Illinois will create a new method for preparing organic nanoparticles. The approach involves the ring-opening metathesis polymerization of a functionalized monomer followed by an extensive series of intra-particle cross-linking reactions. The organic nanoparticles to be developed are fundamentally different than previously described (e.g., dendrimers, nanocrystals, molecular assemblies, etc.) because through the synthesis their size can be controlled from 1 to 100 nanometers and their flexibility is full tunable by controlling the extent of cross-linking. The chemistry is also sufficiently flexible to allow the synthesis of two-part or Janus organic nanoparticles and to allow one or more attachments to the surface and interior of the organic nanoparticle. The broader impacts involve training undergraduate and graduate students, broadening participation through the inclusion of research personnel from groups underrepresented in the chemical science, and continuing a research apprenticeship program for underrepresented minority students at the University of Illinois, Department of Chemistry.

Nanoparticles are materials whose dimensions fall into the range of 1-100 nanometers and have many potential applications including supports for chemical synthesis, light harvesting antennae, platforms for new biomedical imaging agents, and drug encapsulation and triggered release systems. This project aims to study how nanoparticles can be prepared with a very high degree of control over their size and chemical characteristics. The nanoparticles to be studied in this project are made from organic precursors and are expected to be nontoxic and have minimal environmental impact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this award several significant advances have been made.  First, a new chemical synthesis of organic nanoparticles (ONPs) has been developed. These ONPs are polymeric particles that have undergone chemical cross-linking to give them a rigid and well-defined size.  The size and chemical functionality on the surface of the ONPs can be changed in a regular way to change their physical properties.  One series of these ONPs is relatively nontoxic in comparison to many metal nanoparticles that have been developed. As such these ONPs may serve as more useful biological probes. Indeed, they have been prepared with fluorescent dyes within their interiors allowing them to be tracked. The ONPs are taken up by cells and the rate of uptake can be tuned in a regular and predictable way by the nature of the groups on the surface of the ONP. 

The polymeric structure of the ONP has several significant advantages. First, it can serve as a scaffold to carry multiple fluorescent dyes making the fluorescent ONPs extremely bright and, thus, more useful bioprobes.  The polymeric shell also serves to protect the fluorescent dyes to increase the lifetime of the fluorescence allowing the bioprobes to function longer. All of ONPs have a single reactive functional group on their surfaces a structure that has been difficult to achieve in other nanoparticles. These ONPs can linked to single strands of DNA and the ONP can serve as a template for the growth of a metal nanoparticle containing a single active DNA strand on its surface.  This bottom-up synthesis provides access to an important nanostructure—a metal nanoparticle conjugated to a single DNA strand—that is difficult to make in other ways. 

Finally, the polymer scaffold can also carry a catalyst and it has been shown that a copper-containing ONP can perform an important chemical reaction called the “click” reaction. It does so more efficiently than nearly any other catalyst available.  The copper ONP is able to enter live cells and perform the click reaction within the cell.  This allows bioactive agents, that may not enter the cell particularly well, to be synthesized intracellularly.

The broader impact of the work performed under this award is in multiple areas. One is in the study of biological processes within the cell where a bright and long-lived fluorescent probe is needed. Another is in the area of catalysis where the ability to perform the click reaction in water using the copper ONP obviates the need for organic solvents and uses copper at a level that is lower than the maximum contaminant level goal (MCLG) for copper in drinking water (1.3 ppm) as defined by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.  Another broader impact of the work is in the training of a diverse group of researchers at the interface of organic, polymer, and materials chemistry.

Modified by: Steven C Zimmerman

Image
  • Organic nanoparticles with different sizes and functional surfaces enter cells at different rates. The uptake rate can be predictably controlled by the size and surface hydrophobicity.
    Yugang Bai
    Copyrighted
    Steven C Zimmerman
    Organic Nanoparticles Entering a Cell

The ONPs are taken up by cells and the rate of uptake can be tuned in a regular and predictable way by the nature of the groups on the surface of the ONP. The polymeric structure of the ONP has several significant advantages. First, it can serve as a scaffold to carry multiple fluorescent dyes making the fluorescent ONPs extremely bright and, thus, more useful bioprobes.
